awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Interdisciplinary REU in the Structure and Function of Proteins
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the University of Michigan, located in Ann Arbor, MI, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021. Participants will conduct research in the areas of biochemistry, biophysics, computational chemistry, enzymology, molecular biology and plant biology.  The research projects featured in this program mostly involve studies of the structure and function of proteins.  In addition to the research activity, students will participate in a journal club and a series of weekly seminars focused on ethics, scientific communication, career paths in science and graduate school admissions.  Rising sophomores, juniors or seniors majoring in a STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) discipline are eligible for participation.  Interested students must have an interest in pursuing a graduate degree (MS or PhD) and/or a career in a STEM discipline.  All participants must be U.S. citizens or permanent residents. Applications will be reviewed by an admissions committee consisting of several faculty mentors and the PI.  Decisions will be made by mid/late March.

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited opportunities for research, will be trained in the program. Students who are from underrepresented ethnic/racial groups and those who are US veterans or 1st generation college students are strongly encouraged to apply. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. 

A common web-based assessment tool, used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (DBI), will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Additional evaluations and assessments of the program and its impact will be conducted.  Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths and post-program activities. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting https://pharmacy.umich.edu/reu, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Cherie Dotson at crdotson@umich.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Emily Scott at scottee@umich.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Project Outcomes Report is written to share a summary of the outcomes of the Interdisciplinary REU Program in the Structure and Function of Proteins at the University of Michigan (U of M) – Award 1851985.   

Intellectual Merit

Program Goals: The long-term goal of the Interdisciplinary REU Program in the Structure and Function of Proteins is to encourage persistence in STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) disciplines at the undergraduate, graduate and post-graduate levels.  A further goal of the program is to increase the number of women and underrepresented students who are pursuing graduate (M.S./Ph.D.) degrees and careers in STEM disciplines. 

Program Objectives:  The objectives of the Interdisciplinary REU Program in the Structure and Function of Proteins are to: 1) enhance the educational experience of program participants, 2) assist program participants in confirming and clarifying their educational and career goals and 3) encourage participants to pursue graduate (M.S./Ph.D.) degrees and careers in STEM disciplines. 

In support of the achievement of these objectives, students were provided with the following:

  • An authentic interdisciplinary research experience
  • Training sessions on the critical evaluation of scientific papers (Journal Club)
  • Fundamental principles of effective oral & written communication in science
  • First-hand exposure to the culture of graduate school
  • Information regarding the graduate school application process
  • Exposure to career paths in the sciences
  • Training sessions regarding responsible conduct in research
  • Opportunities to interact with peers, graduate students and faculty within the context of science
  • Opportunities to interact with peers, graduate students and faculty in social settings

Additional activities included the completion of assignments (poster, paper, PowerPoint presentation) and the delivery of a poster presentation. 

With regard to outcomes, all participants in the program indicated that the program had an impact on their future educational and career goals.  Results of the Undergraduate Research Student Self-Assessment (URSSA) revealed that the program assisted students in many ways with a few notable responses relative to “Problem Solving,” “Having Confidence in their Ability to do Research,” “Understanding what everyday research work is like,” and in “Preparing a Scientific Poster”

All IREU alumni who graduated have committed to graduate degrees (PhD) or careers in STEM, which is in alignment with the program goals and objectives.

Broader Impacts

The U of M Interdisciplinary REU Program recruits students from across the nation while maintaining a special interest in providing research opportunities to women, 1st generation college students, students from underrepresented ethnic/racial backgrounds and students from institutions with limited resources for research.  Students with no prior research experience are also given special consideration. 

Targeted recruitment efforts involved the sharing of information with faculty / advisor contacts at Minority Serving Institutions (MSI) and at undergraduate research conferences that target students from MSIs and students from ethnic / racial groups that are underrepresented in STEM (e.g. Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minoritized Scientists and Society for the Advancement of Chicanos and Native American Students in STEM).  A total of 25% of applicants were from ethnic/racial groups underrepresented in STEM and 30% of the participants were from MSIs and from ethnic/racial groups underrepresented in STEM.

The program introduced a new series of Diversity / Equity / Inclusion “DEI in STEM” Lunch Chats, which were designed to elevate the participants’ awareness of instances of research issues/abuses that have negatively impacted disadvantaged populations.  The lunch chats focused on topics such as: the origins of HeLa cells, the Birth Control Pill trials in Puerto Rico and several topics of medical research abuse featured in the book Medical Apartheid by Harriet Washington.  It is hoped that these discussions will help our future research scientists and leaders to understand how bias, racism and inequity can be present in research with the hope that they will work to speak out against it. 

 

 


Last Modified: 06/16/2023
Modified by: Cherie R Dotson
